												I have been playing UnReal World since 2004. If the game clocked hours before it came to Steam I would be in the thousands. So let's talk about URW.URW is a roguelike survival game set in Iron Age Finland. It has been made (mostly) by one person and has been in development since 1992. That's 24 years. Talk about dedication. You survive through the four seasons by hunting, gathering, fishing, trading, trapping and farming. You can make a huge variety of items ranging from wooden pots to your very own house and sauna. You will learn the importance of shelter, fire and the advantages of a ranged weapon. Will you be a fisherman hermit? A travelling merchant? Or maybe a proud warrior? You can play the game however you want.There's a steep learning curve to the game since there is simply so much to do. The number of hotkeys on the keyboard rivals Microsoft Flight Simulator. The game does have a good manual and plenty of flavor text for history geeks. And let's not forget the lovely LARP pictures for all the characters.Venture into the Far North. And don't forget to tan your hides.

												I've been playing Unreal World for a few years now, and for as impenetrable as it might look in some of the screenshots, it is actually one of the most understandable and playable roguelikes I've experienced.  It provides a real sense of accomplishment as well.  The first time I finally killed a large animal was as exciting as anything I've experienced in a game.  I had to sit back and just enjoy the accomplishment for several minutes.  When I made the mistake of building a fire too close to my log cabin that I had spent months (in game) and hours (in real life) building, and watched it burn down, I felt a real sense of loss, but also that I had learned something, and was ready to jump back in and try again.  The game's depth and pacing are, in my opinion, what set up these moments.  If you enjoy the survival genre, you owe it to yourself to give this a try.An additional note: the development cycle for this game has been great over the years.  The developers (all two of them) keep the community informed and are constantly making improvements to the game.

												Before I start, I just need to add: you can download this game for free from the official UnReal World website! The free version is practically (if not entirely) identical to the Steam version. Even if you're totally enamoured with this game by the looks of the descriptions and reviews, I still urge people to play the free version before grabbing the Steam one. Once you've given it a shot, you can make a much better decision on if you want to drop money on it. I told myself that if I played the free version for longer than eight hours, I'd buy the Steam version even if I never boot it up again. I clocked about ten hours, bought it on Steam, then continued to play it for however long it says I have at the top of this review.I really love this game. It's deep, but I've never felt truly lost; when you make a character, you can pick to have a goal-orientated quest system that teaches you how to play. This ranges from 'This is how you drink water, you gigantic idiot' to building your own house and trading for animals. Once you've grasped the basics, the game opens up as the survival roguelike it aims to be. If you want to know all the cool mechanics that come with the game, the other positive reviews go into passionate detail about what makes the game great. To avoid clashing with people who have literally hundreds of hours of gametime over me, I'll instead relay something that's unique to me; an in-game story.Fur is really important in UnReal World. It's valuable, it's useful, and it'll stop you from freezing to death when Snow Hell decides to pay a visit. Unfortunately, being a total newbie at the game, the only hides I can get are from squirrels, hares, and ermines. Not very prestigious. The only big hides I had managed to score was one of a bear and an elk, and that's because they fell into a pit trap I set up and became a sitting duck for my volley of arrows. Basically, I'm a bad hunter.One day I'm out in the snow in my bear fur clothes, checking my pit traps to see if any more suckers have taken pity on my awful hunting skills. The traps are on the border between a mire and a forest, set up to channel and capture any animals walking from one area to another. This time, I noticed a wolf on the world map standing in the mire, so I zoom in on the action to see what's going on.Turns out, it's not a wolf. It's a pack of them.At this point of the game, the most dangerous thing I've successfully managed to hunt (that wasn't sitting in a pit and woefully awaiting death) is a fox. All the animals I've come across are basically 'let's see how close I can get before it runs away at the speed of light'. The wolves didn't do that. They decided that I'm up for dinner. They charge at me ("What? Animals attack you in this game?!") and suddenly I'm reaching for my bow. I thought I was a goner, but it turns out that shooting an arrow into the shoulder of a charging wolf is a good deterrent (who knew?). It became a game of scoring a single wound on each attacking wolf to scare them and make them flee. I scored a particularly good hit on one wolf, and I chased down its limping self and attacked its head for a kill. Skinned its fur and butchered its meat and fat. Good stuff.That's when I discovered why wolves were even here in the first place; lying in the middle of the field was a wolf-torn elk. I approached it and checked the hide, and was surprised to see the wolves hadn't mangled it beyond recognition. It was about a quarter of the way through skinning it that I realised the wolves were still around -- just keeping their distance. I decided to grab the skin and forget the butchering, get out while I still could. I didn't need the meat, the fur was the real gold here.So I walk home with some wolf and elk fur under my arms. The total sum of the furs I had back home came to something like 8lbs; the fur I was carring totalled 30lbs. A good catch! I set the wolf fur down and use its fat from the butchering to tan it. I then set the elk fur down and -- wait! I didn't butcher the elk! I don't have any fat to tan it with! 20lbs of fur was threaning to go rotten on me if I didn't find a solution, and fast.I dumped the fur in my cold, 'please don't rot on me' cellar and made a return to the elk. Turns out, so had the wolves, and they had regained their courage. Some nasty nips later, I decided my life wasn't worth some fat and fled.I looked up about the tanning process to try to find alternatives for my elk fur. Turns out, you don't have to use fat. The skinned barks of alder and rowan trees work just as well. Big problem; I lived in a gigantic forest of pine and birch. So begins the race against time to find an alder or rowan tree before my goldmine attracts flies rather than merchants.So I'm darting around the world map, cursing every pine and birch that I see. That's when I find a herd of reindeer milling around. I decided to try my luck, so I zoomed in and took a less-than-hopeful shot at the nearest one, expecting a total miss and all the reindeer to flee. It hits. Fire off a second arrow before the victim has a chance to run. Second one hits.Oh crap. So this is what hunting feels like.The reindeer has been so badly hit, it's practically crawling its way across the floor. I catch up with it and start trying to unload arrows into its head. My aim is so bad that it ends up hitting the shoulder, body, and even one hit on the knee, at which point I reprimanded UnReal World for its poor choice of meme references. It was around the time I decided to equip a javelin and start poking its head that my character falls asleep. Turns out, fighting wolves and lugging fur across a continent really tires a man out. Who knew?I awoke with the reindeer nowhere in sight. I followed its tracks and found it only a short run away, still desperately trying to crawl its way to freedom. I started poking at its head with the javelin until it dies, skinned it, made sure to grab the fat this time, and recovered the arrows I had fired. The fat of the reindeer was enough to tan its own hide, but not enough to tan the elk's. The hunt for the tree was still on.I read up on alder and rowan trees, and found out that they mostly grow in and around villages. So I poked my head into the local village and -- sure enough -- sitting in the middle of the field all proud of itself was an alder tree. The villagers were probably weirded out to see a man walk into their village, cry 'YES!' and then begin frantically carving the bark off of one of their trees. I didn't care. Elk fur was back in fashion, baby.So that's how I went from Small Game Extraordinaire to sleeping in the furs of a wolf, elk, and reindeer, all because I decided to go check my traps for a bit. My bear fur clothes had some nasty wolf bites in them and I had sufffered a few nasty scratches myself, but I could probably line the entirety of my house in fur now. It was about this time I realised that maybe, just maybe, UnReal World is an awesome game and that I'm glad I got it.Stay safe in the cold North, folks!

												What to say about this amazing game?Just play it!Okay, no, that's not fair... you probably want more info than that, right?TL;DRGod-tier survival/crafting roguelike. Considerable learning curve. Awesome community & devs. Unlike anything else you're likely to find. Try it for free: http://unrealworld.fi/General InfoIt's certainly not for everyone... but it's also one of the most unique and fun games I've ever had the pleasure of playing (that's coming from someone who's been playing video games for over 20 years, and with over 1000 games on Steam alone).Roguelikes, as a genre, seem to have had a resurgence in popularity in recent years; ever since Minecraft rocked the gaming world, the whole survival-crafting-building genre has only increased in popularity.UnReal World mixes all of this and gives you a peerless roguelike survival crafting experience. There are no zombies to find here, only bears and Njerpez (not to mention the hunger and cold), but they're more than trouble enough. You'll wish you had something as easy as zombies to deal with! (except, no, hopefully not... no more zombies... too many zombies everywhere)Despite its name, UnReal World also provides one of the most realistic survival experiences I've seen in a game to date (probably the most realistic, really).Do you want to hang out in the highly-populated Driik lands for access to their large villages and have an easy life of crafting and trading? Or perhaps you'd prefer living out in the middle of nowhere to see if you can survive completely on your own, without help from anyone? Maybe you want to see a lot of combat and one day hope to eradicate all the Njerpez?Any of this is possible, and so much more. It's up to you.GameplayUnReal World won't hold your hand; iron-age pseudo-Finland is a brutal place in which to try and survive, no doubt.A lot of modern gamers might be turned off by the initial time investment required to learn how to play the game (not to mention the oldschool graphics; no fancy 3D & particle effects here), but for those that bother, they'll be rewarded with incredibly deep survival gameplay and an experience like no other.The keyboard-based nature of the game might seem unwieldly at first (and yes, there are a lot of keys to memorize) but it offers very smooth gameplay once you get used to it. You can use the mouse for most/a lot of things, but I'd suggest gtting used to the hotkeys; they can drastically improve your experience.UnReal World is a sandbox. There are no set goals beyond "survive". How you go about doing that is up to you.The map is huge, and mostly wilderness. The game's ten different playable cultures (and one non-playable; the Njerpez) all have their own "area" of the map, which determines where you can find settlements. The most interesting of these for a new player would be the Driikiläiset, which can be found in the south-west, as they are the most "urban" and have the biggest villages (which means more trading, which can make one's life much easier).When you create a new character, you choose which culture you come from; each has their strengths and weaknesses in terms of min/max stats, which affects a variety of things. You can also choose which general area of the map you want to start in, and a few other things.Once you begin your game, what you do is entirely up to you. There are no set goals; this is a free-form sandbox game (though quests are coming in a future update!).You can hunt, fish, explore, craft, trade, build yourself a house. Try to settle down, or live as a nomad. Summertime, and the livin' is easy... but you best be prepared for when winter comes around...Combat[coming soon]Crafting[coming soon]Pricing[coming soon]Parting ThoughtsDon't dive into this game expecting to know how to play right away. There are semi-tutorials which will help you along with the basics (start with "Living in the Wild"), but this is a game with a lot of intricacies that you'll learn over time, with experience and trial & error. Easy to learn, hard to master, as they say. Patience is well-rewarded.UnReal World may be new to Steam, but it's been around for a very long time. Its first iteration dates all the way back to 1992! Of course, the game has changed a lot over the years, and will continue to do so for a long time still.Some useful resources, if you need help, are the official forum[z3.invisionfree.com] and the wiki[unrealworld.wikia.com]. Of course, there's also the Steam forum and no doubt some enterprising players will write Steam guides (though none are yet available at the time of this writing).The UnReal World is a great game with a great community: if you have any questions, ask, someone will be happy to help!

												I've played various versions of UnReal World over the past 12+ years, including dozens of hours on this latest version which is being released on Steam. It's got a lot of attributes of a rogue-like: turn-based movement, permanent death, lots of stuff to discover, lots of stuff to craft. Somewhere in its development, more than 10 years ago, it strayed from the path of being a fantasy game to being a simulation of iron-age Finland.The combat system is straight-forward, but unforgiving. The character has skills for various weapons; combat results are based on attacker and defender results; damage is allocated to hit locations after accounting for armor. Positioning matters: getting behind an opponent allows unblocked attacks. Injuries matter: serious blows to the legs can lame or cripple a creature, a hard blow to the head or even torso can stun. Combat can be drawn out or over quickly, depending on the hidden rng and positioning, so new players are advised to tread carefully at first. Or, you can accept that it's a rogue-like, and just get killed and restart.If your character can survive or avoid combats, time will pass. You'll have to keep your character fed or starvation penalties will mount. You'll have to think about water, and warmth, and shelter. And eventually, maybe before your character is fully prepared, winter will arrive. In the UnReal World, winter changes the game. For about five game-months you need to stay warm and stay fed. Every day will be short. Every night will be long. The leading cause of death in winter might be boredom; the cabin fever and the routine of safe survival becomes too much and the player takes a character out to adventure in the great white north, into the teeth of a blizzard. Some of them make it back to their cabins. Having said that, with good fur clothes and ski equipment, a character can do a lot of hunting and trapping through the winter, or timberwork, or any number of other tasks.I think my characters have died every way possible in this game. I'll let you discover the various ways, and head off myself for further adventures. Enjoy!

 Unreal World: Vimba's Review   I don't make many reviews here on steam, but this game deserves one so much. I've also played the game a lot longer before it came to steam and still do.Edit: My low hours is from offline play from the non-steam executable. I don't know why I don't use steam. I guess I'm just used to the other way around. I bought it on steam because I wanted to support the devs. :)There is so much to say about Unreal World, but first I want to start off by saying that this is not a game that everyone will enjoy. Go check out the game on their website for free: http://www.unrealworld.fi/  You have to put in some effort to learn the controls (which don't take long, depending on how custom you are with roguelikes and basic keyboard layout) You also need to be able to use your imagination (which is our greatest gift for video games) to immerse yourself in your own world. Once you feel comfortable with that, you are set.Unreal World sets the player close to the iron age of human history ( 800 - 1200 A.D.) located in Finland. You can see from the start as soon as you launch the game that the traditional and folklore of the finnish culture is in place by listening to the music. The Kantele is being used which is part of the Finnish culture and it immediately tries to immerse the player in its rich world. You choose a culture and then roll some stats. The world is then randomly generated and you get to choose a beginning "story" or setup to how you will play the first moments of the game. Each scenario has some sort of interesting background to help you be ready and immersed in the world. They are all interesting and some provide tools to help you get started.If you survive your initial scenario (depending if you chose a violent one) you are then free to do what you wish. Ultimately Unreal World is a simulator of sorts to show the player how our world is a dangerous one without the need of zombies and Rust like 24/7 violence. Like the Finnish Proverb says "The world will surely teach one; if nothing else, than to walk slowly." It's very true! I won't go into details of what you can do because basically there are SO many things you can do and everything necessary is there to survive. If you were someone that read this because you thought you wouldn't be able to learn this or hate it for the graphics; well good for you b/c there are mods, in-game tutorials, encylopedia, and online guides. Pros + Very Immersive+ A game that allows players to use their imagination+ Awesome Developers (Thanks Sami and Erkka)+ In Depth Combat System+ In Depth Injury System from cuts/bruises, to diseases and so much more+ Accurate Historical Items and Folklore+ Easily Moddable+ High Replayability Cons -Roguelike Graphics: This is a con for some players used to modern graphics (Latest Update Improved them and mods help)-Slight learning curve with keys (but is easily fluid once you get used to it)-Could use more sounds IMO but overall very well done-Pictures are somewhat corny but overall they do well (personal taste and easily moddable and mods help)Overall, this is the TRUE survival game. I have over 400 hours of Rust and have played just about every survival game out there, but Unreal World just keeps pulling me back in for its in depth system of how we humans are adapted to survive in the impossible. This game allows me to use my imagination and do what I cannot do in my daily life. Final Score: 95/100 Thank you so much for reading!

												I was woefully ignorant of this game for many years, which is sad, because this is THE game I always imagined being able to play one day.This is a game with such depth that it could only be an "indie" game. 3D rendering, fancy production, developer time-tables... all of that Big Name Developer stuff would make creating a game like this completely impossible.UnReal World is a procedurally generated (yet large and persistent) world, inhabited by incredible A.I. There are numerous tasks always available for you to do, and the objective is simply to survive. But almost inevitably: you won't.Your character struggles mostly against nature (and the occasional bandit or warrior). The weather, the ice, the BEARS. Go fishing, go hunting, go trading. Make tools and weapons and traps. Whatever you think you could do in an Iron-Age Scandinavian forest, you can do it in this game, with astonishing attention to detail and realism.The animal A.I. is amazing. Wolves split and converge over long-distances with their packs, howling for communication. Kill the biggest reindeer in a pack (the leader) and the other reindeer will become aimless until they're picked off by other prey. Combat, while not action-based, has a cold realism to it unlike anything I've seen. Your life isn't measured in "Hit points"... Rather your body, your limbs, your blood, your senses: they can all be attacked and taken away from you -- or you can take them away from your enemy. One hit in the right spot will debilitate you. Game over. But its a death that will make you smile. Dying is a part of nature, and a part of this game. Fight against it, but realize that its what makes your character's adventure... complete.Hunting in this game is a challenge and never a guaranteed success. You, the player, as a person, need to learn the value of patience and deligence. But when you finally manage to track down your first elk or stag through vast reaches of forest, until at last the animal is too fatigued to run anymore... there is NO "kill" in a videogame I've found as satisfying as this. Yesterday I got really lucky, and chased a panicked reindeer that injured itself trying to scale down a cliff -- but when I finally caught up to it, a wolf had half-eaten its corpse, ruining the precious fur and making off with some of the meat.Smoke/Dry the meat, tan the skin, feed your dog, and donate a cut of meat to the "gods" for letting you live another day. Work on building your cabin, or preparing the cold soil for future agriculture. There is so much to do, and it is all vital, well-designed, brilliant. This is a brilliant one-of-a-kind game that throws you into a real world like no other game I've ever played. There is no game I would more enthusiastically urge people to try. I am so happy this game has come to Steam, thus coming to my attention, and I have never been more happy to give a developer my money (thank you, Sami). Try this game.

												(Please ignore the small amount of play-time I have. I've had this game for around a decade, and the developer has kindly supplied me with a key for the Steam version.)See the bottom of the review for TL;DR.I rarely write positive reviews, but to me, the devotion that Sami shows to his supporters and fans is nothing short of remarkable. He went through the trouble of walking me through the steps of getting my key re-sent and updated despite me having very little of the original information I had when originally purchasing the game, and also has made a point of giving Steam keys to those who own lifetime registration keys.Though, this is a review about URW, not about the developer.URW takes a somewhat different approach to things than a lot of roguelikes, especially the ones usually seen on Steam. Rather than abstracting concepts like HP, satiation, exhaustion, deities, combat, and so on, URW tries as well as it is able to approach things more realistically. Fans of Dwarf Fortress Adventurer Mode shouldn't be too out of their element here.Rather than being about killing dragons and getting amulets, URW is more generally about surviving in the wilderness. Trying to, anyway. Combat poses a very real threat. One missed blow could get you a concussion, or swept off of your feet and getting a spear through your chest, or teeth at your throat. This is made all the more painful, because your characters and the worlds they live in are indeed very permanent. You might build a house and make a type of farm, trading regularly with a nearby village. Make a smokehouse to cure your meats, make a sauna, get drunk, do what people from Finland do.But the combat itself isn't the only problem. You also have to worry about things like your wounds getting infected, illnesses, starvation, dehydration, hypothermia, sleep deprivation. Of course, when you're injured, it becomes even harder to care for yourself... but that might be skipping ahead a little too far. Depending on whatever choice of background and scenario you pick, your first priority might be making a temporary shelter out of sticks and leaves, fending off a wolf, or escaping from captivity.After you make yourself marginally more comfortable, you need to start working on feeding yourself, and making (or trading for, or looting, or stealing) tools as a means to accomplish this. Whether that means hunting for food, fishing, foraging, robbing other people, stealing from them, or just plain killing them and eating them. (The gods won't mind. Really.) But while eating raw food might be okay sometimes, you should probably consider cooking it, making a dish of it, or maybe a bit later on, working on a means of preparing it for long-term storage, like digging a cold-storage cellar, or curing it with salt, or in a smokehouse.Once you have a somewhat reliable means of feeding yourself and living comfortably in the trees, and have a nice axe, hopefully without too many people's blood on it, you could think about building a house for yourself! Or you could live like a nomad. Your choice, really. Either way, once you're on your feet, you can get niceties by trading things like cured furs and pelts to village traders and other wanderers possibly like yourself.Although there are arbitrary goals that can reward you with things, ultimately they are optional and there is no endgame or final goal of URW besides what you dictate.URW is definitely not for everyone, and I do recommend trying the free version first. Don't let my review make the game sound more hypeworthy than it is. See for yourself if you like it or not. Even if you think you like roguelikes, this one might not sit well with you.tl;dr Mostly-realistic wilderness survival roguelike that eventually turns into a violent Harvest Moon with permadeath.TRY THE FREE VERSION FIRST.

Getting frostbite (or just really frustrated) as I try to check them over and over, even though they haven't brought in any game. - Finally making enough headway to build a cabin. Playing an awkward, hilarious, terrifying game of cat and mouse with a lynx that wanders onto my property, until I can manage to get a fence and traps up.My last game, I started out trying to hunt with a bow/arrow. I brought down a bunch of birds with it, but I was gradually starving. I found a grouse that had been partially eaten by a goshawk. Fine, I'm not picky. That's a pound of grouse meat. I ate it. I was tracking a herd of reindeer for days, and when I went up to the mountain to scout out where they'd gotten to, I saw that there were wolves chasing them. I weighed the options, decided I was starving and I'd try to avoid the wolves. Came within a screen of wolves twice, but managed to avoid them, and found a reindeer that the wolves had taken down and started eating. Fine. I'm not picky. I skinned it, butchered it, and brought the meat home.Finally, my trap pits started bringing in big game. Too much big game, in fact -- something like 4-5 reindeer and stags within the period of a week or so. I lost one of the hides when it rotted while I was scrambling to butcher everything, tan the hides, reset the traps, and haul meat up to the closest village before it went bad. So I got sloppy and left a bunch of meat next to one of the traps, where I'd butchered a reindeer but couldn't carry everything back. When I came back for the rest, a wolf was there, attracted by the meat. He lunged at me and took me down in two attacks.Anyway, if you like roguelikes or sandbox games, especially wilderness survival, get this. I always come back to it, that's how good it is, and it's constantly being improved (dynamic weather, predator-prey interaction, and more realistic animal spawning are all very new, and they're amazing, and I'm sure we can expect more of the same quality changes in the future). It's got a heck of a learning curve, but it basically defined sandbox games for me, way back before Minecraft was even a thing.

												I've been playing this game for years and it just keeps getting better and better with every iteration.  It's nice to see it up on steam where it will get more exposure and bring a great deal of enjoyment to many others who discover it.It is a rich single-player world where you will have to survive.  No, not one wave after another of enemies, but the harsh realities of living in a land where even the weather can be your enemy.  Yes, there are some (NPC) people whom you might have to fight with, but many more whom you will trade with and develop a relationship for mutual survival.  You pick a spot to make your cabin.  Cut the trees to make the logs.  Fish.  Hunt.  Plant.  Make your tools or trade for them with nearby villagers.  Stock up on foods, make warm clothing and much, much more... and maybe,  just maybe, you'll survive the cold, dark winter.I enjoy the turn-based aspect of this game, allowing me to go at my own pace.  Graphics are tiled top-down and not spectacular, but with each iteration of the game, they get better and better.  This latest version the graphics (particularly the lighting) add a lot to immersion.   It doesn't really matter though, because you soon get lost in the details and become immersed in the world no matter what.  How much snow fell while you were sleeping, do I need to use my skis?  Has it been cold enough to go out on the ice?  The edges of the lake are solid, but is the middle safe enough to walk on?  Did I hear a Elk in the distance to my left?  I better check my trap lines.  I wonder if the village I discovered earlier last week has some better spears to trade for.  There were  rumors of a bear in the area and it's hide would make nice warm clothing for cold winter days.... and on it goes.Modding is easy and enjoyable, especially with this new version, allowing you to tweak many things or make completely new ones.  The creators of the game are also responsive to the community and very friendly.I don't really have anything negative to say. It might take a little time to get used to the key commands, but the help file is easily accessible after hitting the ESC key.  The game does what it's suppose to and just gets better and more detailed with every iteration.  It's turn-based, survival, wilderness simulation that makes for a great afternoon or evening of play.  I'd say try it out, the price is very reasonable.

Before I knew it I was slightly interested. My slight interest and curiosity got me to download the free version of this game and give it a good college try. After about an hour I knew this was something special. Something I could play for years if not for once in a while. You are in control of a tribesmen or women of sorts set to survive in the great iron north. You can customize your starting story which impacts your starting gear and situation respectively. You can also customize where you start and whether the tutorial is active or not. From there is up to you create a marvelous adventure filled with peril, exhaustion, starvation, infection, and whatever else might kill you. The game mechanics make sense and feel realistic. Chopping a tree down with a knife takes hours unlike using an axe, chasing down a reindeer or badger is unlikely, etc. It’s not perfect but it works. This game kind of reminds me of a ‘create your own adventure book/board game’. Time progresses as you perform actions and move around the world. This gives you time to think about your next action. Do you try and sneak up on that wild pig or do you chunk this rock on the ground at it? Knowing that if you miss it’s probably going to get away. Should I eat this spoiled food knowing it might make me sick? Death is permanent so make every choice count! Every action performed is checked against multiple stats. Reminds me of the old DnD days. Makes the world feel more immersive and the combat feel richer. You want to throw that spear? How fatigued are you? What’s you skill in spears? Are you injured? How far away is the target? I don’t know all the exact stats but I know there is a lot going on in the background for everything you do. I recommend that you just watch a couple video and try it out for yourself. Download the free version at their website. If this sounds good to you then you owe it to yourself to give it a good college try like I did. I will leave you with a brief adventure that I had in the Unreal World… Alone, cold, and starving I come across a lonely reindeer in the middle of a vast frozen forest. He doesn’t notice me so make a slow approach. As I approach I snap a small branch beneath my foot like an idiot which alerts the reindeer to jump to attention. It’s now or never. I draw and shoot my bow. The shot is steady and accurate but the reindeer is already in motion. The arrow penetrates just below the reindeer’s shoulder. It takes off into the dense woods. I follow. After a short while I start to lose sight of it and I am relying on my tracking ability alone. Tracks and blood keep focused. As night beings to fall I start to loose site of its trail. It’s getting dark and I am starting to lose hope. My stomach growls and I begin to shiver. The cold is taking a hold of me I am beginning to fail. Then I hear something to my south. A yell of an animal. Do I continue on or follow the sound? I hear the yell again. After losing complete site of the reindeer tracks I decide to follow the sound. After about 10 minutes of travelling south I see it… It’s the reindeer I shot earlier. It nearly doubled backed on me. It’s injured, crippled and fatigued. “You’re mine now!” I draw and fire my bow. I am so fatigued the arrow hits the tree next to it. Again! I draw and shot my bow. The arrow flies true and I hit it straight in the neck; blood rushes out. It slows and after a few steps staggers then passes out. I approach and finish the job.I take a moment to rest but I am too cold to stay still for too long. Night has fallen and I need to rest. I quickly gather some branches and firewood and make a fire. The warmth of the fire gives me a second wind an I decide to skin the animal and butcher some of its meat. I am so hungry I feast on it raw like a ravenous dog. Its late, taking satisfaction of a good kill I decide to sleep for the night. Unfortunately the fire goes out in the middle of the night and I awake in the early hours of the morning chilled yet again. I hear something approaching... I take a moment to scan my surroundings and notice my reindeer has been feasted upon. What could of done this? A dog? No... A bear. As I turn I see the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ himself. I take a step back and it approaches. I draw my bow and take the shot. My shot is steady and true puncturing the bear in the front of his chest. It’s not enough. It becomes enraged and begins to charge. Before I can react It swipes its massive claw and gashes my arm and chest wide open. I fall back… I reach for my knife... It finishes me off with a mighty blow. Hugh Glass would of been disappointed... This is just one of my wonderful adventures. Many more await you in the Unreal World. 10 bear tracks out of 10.

(Unlike Rust/The Forest/ and others that make the claim)+ High Replayability.+ Immersive Lore.+ Progressive skills.+ Massive crafting system.+ Extensive Medical system.+ Many mods made by the community and refined over time.+ Easy to create your own mods. Google the resources you need and the system is easy to learn.Cons:-- Mixture of Traditional & Digitized sprites for graphics.-- Complex context menus required for maneveuring through the game.- Basic/dated sound effects.Neutral (Because this could be a plus for some, a negative for others.)* +/- Overall a dated old-school look and feel.  +/- A slight lack of "end-game" content, but reaching the end-game takes plenty of time and new updates are planned to rectify this.  A few of the planned updates are: family management, village ceremonies, and more. This is all detailed on the development page.  +/- End game content  by 3rd party developers. I think that a game's merit shouldn't be based off the content created by the community, but while you're waiting on new updates things like the Shaman mod can give you your fix of additional content. It adds many "rituals" that feel lore-friendly and allow you to delve into spiritual magic and ultimately align yourself with light or darkness.+/- It is lacking in music overall, but the new title screen music is promising.Due to the time when the project was initially started the game has been stuck in the past as far as graphics, sound, and the general presentation goes.The skin isn't beautiful, but the meat is sturdy and supple. [It must be a Kaumo.]For those who aren't deterred by the time investment it takes to learn this game it is worthwhile and has more to come.You can check out the developer's plans over on the website under the Development tab. http://www.unrealworld.fi/urw_development.htmlProtips for those who intend to buy it/already have:(I'll update this as I think of more.)! Use the mouse wheel to zoom in/out. This is very useful for hunting.! The help menu is your friend. Even for seasoned veterans.! Dogs are man's best friends for a reason. They make hunting much easier.! Humans used to use a method called "Persistence Hunting" to hunt down big game. The short of it is you use your incredible endurance to run an animal down and track it until it collapses from exhaustion then shower it with arrows or beat it to death in its sleep. How metal is that?! Try to spawn close to the Driikiläiset people (Cyan on the map, toggle culture colors on) so that you can trade with their massive amounts of shops if you find a village. You'll do quite well for yourself by peddling your crafts to them for various supplies.! Trap fences can be difficult to get the hang of, but making a house relatively near one can help guarantee your cellar stays stocked throughout the winter.! When starving and tracking down an animal have ranged weaponry. You miss 100% of the shots you don't take -Lebron James on hunting, maybe.!!! Don't give up. Every death is a chance to learn or try something different although it is frustrating to lose your progress. If you really don't want to lose out on it (and this is often frowned upon, but your own choice) then you pull up task manager (Control + Alt + Delete) and end the URW.exe process before going through the menu that deletes your character/progress. Everything that happened up to your death will be the same when you reload the game. You lose out on the experience, but it is your purchase and decision.EDIT:  Actually, since I was born in 1992 and the game was released then it has been in-dev all my life. Wow.

UnReal World is a unique and remarkable addition to the roguelike genre. I played this for many hours with the free version before it came to Steam. At times I feel like this is a slightly more 'zen-like' experience than many of its dungeon-crawling brothers, simply because there does not always have to be a clear-cut goal of getting to the bottom of a dungeon or escaping something. In exchange for dungeons, you get the great Finland outdoors. Sometimes you just chill out and exist. But don't get me wrong, the learning curve is still quite steep and you will 100% always die on a long enough timeline. This is Don't Starve for the hardcore (I write that with a loving nod to Don't Starve). The flavor of this title is potent, and very much its own thing. This does not play or feel like anything else out there, as far as I'm concerned. It can't accurately be described as just some sort of 'different angle' or 'take' on another game. The obscure mixture of old-school artwork with, well, old-school real life images is weird, but after a while it becomes alluring. The text is well written. I like the 'online' in-game encyclopedia and deep lore. You could get lost in this universe for a life-time and probably still not experience everything.Overall, I really have no "con's" to list. This is a classic roguelike that is a pillar of the community, and deserves recognition as such. The controls are awkward at first, for sure, but quickly you get used to them and actually like them (plus there are options for traditional roguelike controls). Like any roguelike worth its weight, you will explore, die, learn why you died - and repeat to hopefully make it further. You will have a good time.So go ahead - pick this up and get lost for an afternoon... Or a weekend... Or a lifetime. You won't regret it.

												I have always been a big fan of open world games, as well as games that include random generation. Unreal World is both of these, along with many other themes that are so incredibly rare to find bundled into a single game. I know anything I say in this review will not come close to doing the game justice, but I hope I can sway any readers into trying this wonderful gem if they are a fan of this kind of game.Unreal World is based on Finland during the late iron age, roughly 800 - 1200 AD. While there a few fantasy themes in Unreal World, I consider this game to be pretty realistic. The fantasy themes I mentioned are mostly your character's religous beliefs, which are modeled after Finnish beliefs during the time period. If you have to swim across a river for example, it is a good idea to perform a ritual to "banish the evil water guardian" so that you will be less likely to drown in the process.The game is a huge world to explore, randomly generated for every character you make. When you create your character, after selecting what tribe you are from, picking a character portrait, and other things, you will be able to pick a starting scenario if you wish. The scenario doesn't affect the gameplay, only the circumstances you begin the game with. Will you be an aspiring farmer, starting the game with a shovel and some seeds to start your very own farm? Or perhaps you have come across an abandoned campsite, with its creator nowhere to be found? There are many ways to start your game, and as many ways to play the game as you can imagine. There are no restrictions of what you can and can not do. Will you build a cabin far off into the woods, trapping animals and selling their fur to a nearby village? Or maybe you prefer the life of a hermit, living off the land, avoiding human contact completely.I can ramble all day about this game, but like I said, anything I say in this review is not going to even come close to how great this game is. If you are a fan of wilderness survival games, this game is for you. Some people may be turned away because of the old school graphics, but I can tell you without any doubt in my mind that this game more than makes up for that with the incredible amount of realism it contains, along with a refreshing break from the modern world to a time so long ago, it seems totally unreal.

												I have been playing URW since 2001, version 2.60.  After 15 years it's awesome to finally see it come to the mainstream public attention, and I have nothing but praise for the game.At its core, it's your basic roguelike game: perma-death, turn-based, keyboard-heavy and with 2d pixel tiles instead of fancy graphics. Actually, it started out way back (it's in development since 1992) as a fairly standard fantasy game, but then slowly transformed into a realistic life simulator in the setting of iron age Finland.You will have to survive by crafting needed stuff, hunting/gathering/fishing/putting out traps and get food, wood and pelts to make items and/or to trade for things you can't craft like axes or pots, and get better armor and weapons to fight off wild beasts and nasty humans (they come in the form of either bloodthirsty Njerpez warriors that will only settle for your death, or simple robbers that will try to get your stuff either by talking or by bludgeoning you over the head). Also of course you'll get tired and need to sleep, eat, and drink.The game has a day-night cycle, full-on weather and seasons system: in summer the temperatures are bearable even without being covered head to toe in furs, berries and plants to eat are readily available, there's plenty of game to hunt and life is generally easier (you will get mauled by a bear nonetheless, don't worry)At the other end of the spectrum, winter is harsh: days are short and nights are long, it gets freezing cold and you WILL die from hypothermia so you have to build shelter, possibly an elaborate log cabin complete with fireplace, table and bed, make enough firewood to keep warm and get a decent source of food or a good plan for having enough in those long, boring months. Ice will cover the rivers and lakes so to fish you'll have to poke holes in it, and if you're not careful you can walk on thin ice that will break and drop you into freezing water. Also snow accumulates on the ground and unless you have skis, you won't be able to walk very long without getting incredibly tired so you better have everything you need not too far away. On the upside it also allows you to spot tracks much easier. Too bad there are few animals around in winter...I could speak about the game all day but this would become too long, so I'll just say one last thing, and it's the thing that impressed me most:This game is a labor of love. Over the many years I've been playing this, a LOT of things have changed, and always for the better. Just since last year or so, there's a totally new trading / reputation system with villages, most exploits have been squashed and replaced with sensible mechanics, you can command your pet dog and it's even more of a killing machine, new animal AI especially for predators that will actively hunt their prey (have sheeps in a pen? be careful of wolves!), addition of more birds and seals you can club, and the list goes on and on. It's a truly well supported game that is worth at least double what they're asking, so if you're interested in this kind of game and don't mind that it's keyboard-heavy and has 2d graphics, it is a MUST BUY.

You will need a javelin or a spear as a minimum.And as you begin to build your house, possibly expand your fishing operations with nets, grow crops, hunt and make traps for meat and furs, watch as your skills improve the more you use them, and start to prepare for the winter by making your own clothes or bartering for the things you need from nearby villages, you'll begin to really appreciate the progression you are starting to make.All in all, a great game which eschews graphics and sound for greater depth and what many games forget about nowadays: gameplay.

												I've played this game since before it was on Steam, and I've always found it fun to play. Now, however, I can leave a review!So, this game won't be for everyone. I can gush about it for hours, but it's important that you understand that if I like it, that doesn't have to mean you will. That's why I will start outlining the things that may make this game not fit for everyone.Cons:The graphics are simple and have little merit to them. They're merely there to make the game accessible. If you have a problem with simple graphics, this game is not for you.The controls are not very good. Once again, they're just there in order to be able to control the game, and to play this you'll have to remember or look up a bunch of key combinations. Luckily, you can do this in-game. This'll become muscle memory after a while, but if you're starting out it can be quite difficult.The game has no difficulty curve. There is one difficulty, and while you have the merit of starting out with some useful stuff and you can delay winter by starting early in the year, you're going to have to learn how to deal with the game's challenges. And this game can be hard, especially if you're not sure what to do.The game can be a grind. You have to focus on both the long term and the short term, which often means you'll have to do the same thing for weeks on end in an effort to reach some long term goal, and especially early on you'll be restricted when you're just beginning to make a living for yourself.Pros:This game has great depth. While it's certainly possible to understand the game mechanics, there are always things that will surprise you are possible. As an example, I once got knocked in the eye while climbing a tree, and I was astounded that my field of vision was actually decreased by this.The game world is huge. It's not endless, but there is plenty of room to do anything you wish.There are a lot of interesting skills, and they're not trivial to master. From weatherlore to timbercraft to tracking, there's plenty of skills to spend your time refining and reap the benefits from.There's a lot of things you can build and do. You could become a carpenter who sells their crafts for food, or a hunter, who is self-sustaining but has to travel a lot. Each option is interesting and provides you with a new style of play, needing to focus on different things to be successful.Realism. Harsh realism. This game is not forgiving, and a single mistake can lead to a series of events that ends with you dying alone in a pit surrounded by wolves. There are of course limits to this, but a few of the things you will need to keep an eye on during your travels are temperature, thirst, nutrition, carrying capacity, wounds, disposition with the locals, time of year, state of your clothes, and quality of your tools and items.In the end, there's just a lot you can do in this game, and it's great to see your plans come together as you slowly build up resources, self-sufficiency, and social contacts among the locals.The price of 10,99 is great, and the amount of content you'll get is certainly worth that price.This game sets out to place you, on your own, in a harsh, wild land in the ancient North, and it captures that feel well. You'll often be struggling to survive, cold, undernourished, or low on supplies, with no traces of civilization for miles around.This game is not for everyone, but if you've made it this far into the review and you're still considering buying it, this game certainly is for you.

												Have you ever wondered what being a Finn was like before the invention of alcoholism, anime, severe depression and murdering Russians? Well now, through the magic of computer roleplaying, you can at last find out!This game is a pretty innovative blend of roguelike and survival simulator that dates back to several decades before the current survival game craze. The presentation and interface are true to that era, and so really shouldn't be a hindrance unless you're a millenial casual babby, in which case I congratulate you on managing to read this far without losing interest and playing with your smartphone, you little♥♥♥♥♥♥ The only area where this doesn't really hold is with certain repeated commands - putting down several fishing nets in succession involves a number of awkward key combinations, and the process of chopping down trees and hauling them to a location (which you WILL need to do if you want a house) will inevitably strain your fingers to the point where you will certainly come to sympathize with your likewise strained and fatigued character.Besides that, the graphics are charming and effective - the sprites stand out, look good and tell you what you need to know, and the menus are decorated with quaint images of Finnish cosplayers in their natural habitat.But enough about that nonsense! You want to hear about gameplay! The areas where this game really excels are its depth, realism and immersiveness. You begin play at a season of your choice, either in the wilderness or in a friendly, desolate or hostile settlement, depending on the starting scenario of your choice, equipped with either very little or nothing at all to help you weather the oncoming trials. From that point on, you have just one overarching goal: survive.This isn't nearly as easy as you might think - not because everything is trying to kill you (in fact, the opposite is more likely to be true), but rather because getting the necessities of life is hard. Hunting, for example, requires that you first find prey - which involves a great deal of fruitless wandering and scouring the land for tracks. You might follow a fresh and promising trail to the point where you're only a hair's breadth away from your quarry, only to have it suddenly go cold, prompting profound disappointment. If you do find prey, your problems only multiply, as you then have to make a decision - do you close the distance and risk spooking the game in order to get a better shot? Or take the one you have, and risk missing to the same effect?Managing risks and resources is in many ways the core of the gameplay. You have to choose not only how to conduct your activities, but which activities to embark on, as each have their associated risks and rewards. A hunt is likely to fail, can be dangerous, and is wont to leave you far from home and exhausted come night time. Fishing is safe, but consumes large amounts of your time and might return nothing at all, or an insufficient catch. There are no sure bets, however, and you'll inevitably have to go all in at some point. Sometimes you'll fail. That's just life.Likewise, every activity has its associated costs. Not necessarily in resources, but always in your character's time and energy. Building a house will give you a leg up, but chopping down trees and hewing logs is hard work that's sure to leave you with an appetite, and to make it worse, all that time you spent doing that was time you didn't spend acquiring food. Consequently, much of the earlier game is an exercise in building a big enough stockpile to be able to do more time-intensive work without worrying about what you'll eat tomorrow. This is difficult, as the most easily acquired foods (fish and meat) spoil rapidly without some means to preserve them, and even if you do get lucky enough to kill an elk early on, there's no way you can eat all the resultant meat all by yourself before it will spoil.Still, though, overcoming all of those challenges as they come at you brings on a sense of elation like little else in video games. Sure, half of it might just be dying in the cold and worrying about tomorrow's meals, and sure, the Njerpez will kill your favourite dog, and sure, you might acidentally give your pants away for a handful of peas, but everything becomes worth it when you can sit down and look with pride upon your big house, blooming fields and cellarful of dried meats. It's an extremely immersive game, equal parts harsh and rewarding, and frighteningly easy to get lost in. There's far less cannibalism involved than I remember from the last time I played it, but I would still highly recommend it if you're into deep and immersive sandbox RPGs.

												Where do I start? UnReal World has been around and in active development a long time. The very first version was in 1992, which was vastly different from the game we have now. I personally have owned it for 10 years now, and in that time it has just kept getting better and better. I can't even begin to guess how many thousands of hours I've played this game over the years. I come back after every major update to find fresh new features to explore, with the basic meat of the game just as fun as I have always found it.It's an amazing iron age survival simulation, the best I have played.You create a character, choosing a tribe - each with their own genetics (affects attributes, height, build), knowledge (skills, auto-identification of certain plants, which rituals you might start with), and starting gear. Then you can select from a variety of starts to get things rolling - like being an escaping slave (good luck getting away from the camp full of your former masters) or an unfortunate hunting trip (will you kill the animal that killed your father, or flee?). You also pick which season to start in - each with their own challenges. From there you can either do the basic missions, which are there to get you acquainted with the game and give you attainable early goals; do the advanced missions, which are a bit more difficult and require more time; or just strike off and do your own thing.Like any good survival game, you need to provide the basics for your character. You'll need a steady source of food - from hunting, fishing, trapping, foraging, farming, or trading. Just make sure you don't misidentify that mushroom and eat a poisoned one, and don't fall in your own trap pit - especially if you filled it with spikes. You will also need shelter. Options here are a very basic lean to made from spruce branches, a kota (Finnish tent) made from hides that you can pack up and move with you, or a permanent log cabin. Having a smoke house with a fireplace comes in handy for smoking meat, which is one of the easiest ways to preserve your meat. Cellars are also handy to keep your food fresher longer. Need some help building your cabin? Hire a woodsman to cut some trees down for you, some good food may be all he wants.And warm clothes are a must for when the temperature drops, so don't forget to skin that stag and tan its fur for a nice warm set of clothes. Or just for trading, a good fur is valuable. Maybe you'll use it to buy a dog to come along as your companion, helping to keep you safe from robbers and dangerous animals - just don't forget to feed it. The hunting in this game is challenging and fun. Most animals are faster than you, but you have more endurance and you can sneak. Hounding an elk and running it down until it tires out is possible if your character's speed and endurance are decent, as long as you can track it well enough through the woods as it flees to keep on it. Especially if you manage to put an arrow or javelin in it when you first spot it, as a wounded animal runs slower. If you don't have luck actively hunting, you can set traps. From small loop snares all the way up to large lever traps and spiked trap pits, you can set a trap for whatever animal you're trying to hunt. Don't forget to bait them with meat if you're after carnivores. If hunting isn't your style, you can fish. Fishing rods, clubs, or spears round out the active fishing options. Or get yourself a punt or raft and some nets for passive fishing. Or be a farmer and supplement your diet with a variety of grown crops - peas, turnips, rye, beans, hemp, and more.Or you could go straight up vegetarian, eating berries and bread and porridge and farmed vegetables. Just don't expect a vegetarian life to be easy in Iron Age Finland - meat and fish are the best sources of protein around. A balanced diet is easier to manage.The animal AI in the game makes for some fun scenarios. Here is an example of a hunt I had recently:I saw an Elk in the distance from the mountain near where I was building my homestead, and decide it's time to stock up on meat before the weather gets too hot for drying (started in Spring, still early enough).I go hunting for it, and put an arrow in it when I find it - giving it a bleeding wound in the thorax. It runs and I begin the chase, relying on my good tracking skill and endurance to make up for its speed advantage. Soon I notice new tracks intermingled with the Elk. Bear tracks! I continue following the Elk, and the Bear tracks are right there with it all the way.After a while of tracking I finally find my prey, still carrying my arrow... on the ground partially eaten! Bear tracks lead away to the west. 												I don't always review games I play on Steam, but when I do it's something I've consistently enjoyed and kept coming back to for more than a decade.URW is a survival roguelike set in fictional iron age Finland. The emphasis is strongly on realism, with a few light magical elements in the form of rituals and animism. The pace is slow, and unless you get ambushed by the occasional roving bandit or the game's faux-Novgorodian Njerpez warriors, fighting can generally be avoided. Trouble is easy enough to find if you go expressly looking for it, but combat can be brutal and strong armor and weapons are not easy to come by. Death is permanent, as tends to be the genre standard, and the world is not persistent. There's nothing permanent to unlock across playthroughs either, so unless you're cool with manual "save scumming" it's straight back to square one when you kick the bucket.Technically the game ticks a lot of the usual roguelike check boxes. There are quite a few keystrokes and commands to learn for various actions, as well as menus and stat screens to master. Graphics are a mix of simple but decent-looking pixel art and photos, and apart from small objects (such as arrows from missed shots) sometimes being difficult to spot in the middle of a thicket, they get the job done. The soundscape consists mainly of birds chirping, wind rustling through the trees, water splashing and other wilderness ambience.In summary, if you enjoy epic questlines, clear objectives and lots of mysteries to discover, URW might not be for you, but if roguelikes are close to your heart and you're ready for a more down-to-earth survival experience, you should give it a whirl. If you're unsure, you can even download an older version for free from the game's website (http://www.unrealworld.fi/).

I've been following this game for years and I can tell you three things about it you need to know.First, the developers are great guys: super friendly, polite, attentive and eager to interact with the players.Second, there have been constant improvements. The update cycle is a bit long compared to the industry, but they never give up, they never declare "It's done" and move on to something else. Expect a major update that adds something big about once a year, minor updates a little more often, and a burst of hotfixes at every major interval to squash bugs.Last, and most importantly, the simulation is realistic. It isn't watered down with artificial difficulty like swarms of monsters at night or gamey magic potions that fix all your boo-boos. So what is Unreal World?Unreal world is roguelike survival simulation in a procedural world inspired by iron age Finland. Your primary goal in the game is to survive as long as you can. Sort of imagine if Don't Starve had a love child with Robinson's Requiem.It uses a skill based system, with improvement by use. Equipment is varied by both type and quality. Armor and clothing is by location with overlap across more than a dozen body locations. The seasons are fully realized with weather, effects on plants and wildlife and hazards such as heat exhaustion or frostbite. The health system is detailed; tracking individual injuries, pain and infection all with realistic treatment options. Wounds take time to heal and affect your fuctioning.It includes multiple survival strategies to utilize, each modeled to reflect the actual nature of that activity. Hunting, for instance, involves lots of tracking followed by frantic quick shots and pursuit of prey. It's easy to lose your quarry but a successful kill will keep you fed for a long while. Trapping involves a lot of work up front but gives sporadic gains. Farming is a nearly guaranteed result assuming you can live until harvest.You can hunt, fish, farm, trap, raid or trade with villages, raft down rivers or across lakes, capture or buy and then raise animals, build shelters and cabins, fence in areas, gather seasonal plants mushrooms and medicinal herbs, fight with a variety of weapons, craft or trade for and wear a variety of tools clothing and armor.The game is mod friendly. I had the good fortune to be one of the first modders (I added ironworking and clothmaking). Want to change your starting skills? You can mod it. You can alter the item recipes or even add ones the developer didn't include. Heck, you can even add in new plants and mushrooms!If you like roguelikes or survival games, this is a 'must try'.

SummaryIt is a realistic survival simulator. It is a rogue-like. Starting from sticks & stones, build and trade whatever you need to survive the unforgiving Northern Europe. There are no classes, levels, hitpoints... just you, your survival skills, knowledge and pure nature as far as eye can see, and quite a bit more after that.Gameplay Highlights  It is turn based, it is played by mostly keyboard, but some actions are simplified with a mouse.  You can choose tribes for various initial bonusses to skills, and starting items, then use skills to train and develop them.  There are no limitations based on skills or item quality (although tasks require specific types of items). The end result, and how long it takes to get there varies by skills and item quality.  Damage modelled as wounds inflicted on specific body parts, and blood loss.   Hunger and thirst are fairly realistic, in fact this game has the most realistic hunger and thirst simulation I've ever seen.  Objects and actions behave as expected. Recipes make sense. There are no mysterious crafting recipes like "wood + rock = hand gun"  The game is difficult. It will take a while to survive beyond the first week, it may even take a few tries to get to that point. Oh, and there are no guard rails. You can die within the first day.  Some items, including some common items, cannot be crafted, and must be traded for. This may initially be irritating. Have you played roguelikes with keyboard before? Are tired of classic RPG elements like hit points and levelling and classes? Are you looking for a wilderness survival simulation? 3 Yes= Buy this game. 1-2 Yes = Download the free version from http://www.unrealworld.fi, see if you like it. If you do, consider buying it here to support the development.  3 No = Probably not for you, but who am I to say?

												Hands down one of the best roguelikes I've ever played. Played the free version on and off in the past before buying it on Steam to show my modest support and appreciation for the Devs.Being developed and consistently updated for over 20 years, Unreal World is set in a world resembling ancient Finland in the Iron Age. The gameplay has a ton of freedom and depth, and the setting is rich in its historical atmosphere and lore. There are many ways to play, you could be a farmer, hunter, a gatherer, a fisherman, a adventurer or trader as you find your path in this harsh, gritty world. There are no set rules, you decide where to go and what to do. Despite the simple graphics the gameplay is very realistic. It takes creativity and experience to accomplish some of the harder tasks like hunting. You really feel like you're part of the world as you make your way through the four seasons every year.The game has its roots as a ASCII-based roguelike. If you've never played one of those before it might seem daunting to learn the controls, since for these games there're a lot of commands, akin to playing a flight simulator on the keyboard. It honestly isn't too hard to learn, and the in-game help browser and beginner game course is actually very helpful. If you don't mind learning the controls or if you're already a roguelike enthusiast like me, I highly recommend giving it a try.

												This is a one of the best all time survival, hunting, fishing, building, fighting, exploring, bartering, crafting, pretty much everything sims. Don't let the hours here fool you, I've put hundreds (maybe thousands) of hours into this game long before it got onto Steam. The game is fantastically replayable, which is good as you will be replaying it a lot when your characters die, over and over. I would not describe the game as brutal, since there are some starting scenarios that actually set you up quite well if you just want to get to a point where you're stable and can focus on building a house, crafting, and trading. But the game IS unforgiving. No matter how well equipped you are, you'll need to think twice about taking on a Njerpez warrior (even alone) or going after that bear you see across the marsh. One missed swing or shot by you and one solid hit from your opponent (especially if that opponent is a bear) can end you all at once. Or maybe just give you a little scratch that you can tend to while you're sorting through loot or tanning a bear hide to make yourself a nice winter coat. That unpredictability that faces all violent interactions within the game can put some players off, but is a huge draw to others like myself. And if you're looking at a game like this, you're probably one of those kinda of players anyway!While the game has tons of content and an absolutely enormous, randomly generated world to play in, the one downside is that it suffers from something of a "late game" drag. I hate late game in the context of Unreal World since you can play for as long as you can keep your character alive, but when you've survived one full year and you're comfortable enough to sit for days on end at your homestead crafting or resting and not have to worry about feeding or clothing yourself, you'll know you've arrived at the "late game". However, once better interaction mechanics are implemented with NPC communities (something that is in the pipeline), this period will be vastly improved. In the meantime, what most players seem to do is pick harder scenarios, pack up and move, go on a really long expedition, or start taking on riskier endeavors (such as aforementioned bear hunting and Njerpez fighting. If you're worried your character has become to comfortable, remember there are always "fun" ways to live on the edge in Unreal World.

												Been playing URW for about 15 real life years. Or was it even more? Was the first game I ever bought. If you can get into it, it's a vast and unique world you never get tired of.  A massive archipelago. Go anywhere, survive adversity, hoard provisions and steal tools from villagers. Hunt reindeer and elk, tan their skins, smoke the meat, huddle by the campfire all night with your small dog hoping those howling wolves will not dare close in if you keep the fire bright...  Build your own wood house, start an animal pen, milk cows, learn how to hunt with self-made animal traps...My most recent adventure involved hunting seals with bow and arrow, while paddling on a raft in the western seas.  Got so much blubber it will hopefully last the whole winter after being salted.  This world is beautiful and natural in its own way, like no other. There is no special focus on the player usually seen in most roam-anywhere games, no big milestones pre-placed for him. You're just in the wilderness, and you're on your own, tet-a-tet with the whole world. The world in URW does not care if the player lives or dies, but if he lives, there is an unspoken expectation by the unseen spirits of the land that you will show them proper ritual gratitude for this favour.It is the most hardcore game:  complex keyboard-based controls, no hand holding. Also the gameplay is UNFORGIVINGLY realistic. If you've not been preparing well, the very first winter in URW will kill you. Your first couple characters, I'd be well impressed if they survive for more than a week in the wilderness.  "Ohh delicious-looking unknown mushrooms, let me nourish myself with those... welp, dead by morning after exruciating poisoning agony." Slowly you the player gather important Knowledge on what to do ("always boil unknown mushrooms first"), creating your own strategies and best practices. And your survival times increase in proportion, from being measured in hours, to days, to months, to years...On that cheery note, this game is highly recommended to the dedicated and thoughtful players. Absoutely one of my favorite games of all time, and it constantly keeps getting better with each patch. Good luck understanding and loving the Unreal World!

												UnReal World is one of the deepest survival simulators you'll ever come across.  I've been playing it now for around 6 years outside of Steam and it's one of those games you keep coming back to.  It's got a tremendous amount of complexity, which can be very daunting for new players.  Once you make it past the substantial learning curve, you'll find a deeply rewarding survival simulator with a unique setting: medieval Finland.I would term this game a "rogue-like life simulator" if anything.  With the majority of the ongoing game development being focused on adding real-life depth, this means the graphical end of things is more along the lines of the traditional rogue-like games, being more minimalistic.  That also means there's a staggering amount of things you can do in the game.  First timers will more than likely be completely overwhelmed by the different abilities and skills available.  You may want to watch a video or two of someone playing the game to get an idea of things you can do and how to survive in general as you are likely to die rather quickly in the beginning of the most basic of things, like not finding water.This game won't be for everyone.  The high amount of focus on real-life features means you'll be spending a lot of time doing basic survival things like gathering just enough food and water to live off of at the moment.  You also need to be concerned about the variety of your diet the same as in real life.  There's no true in game goal other than to survive as long as possible.  Again, these are things you should be able to tell pretty quickly if they're for you or not by finding a couple of videos of the game being played.If you're into survival games and living off the land in the wilderness sounds like fun to you, this is the game to get.

												UnReal World is an engaging survival roguelike with an amazing amount of depth. You're alone in the wilderness set in the iron age of finland. You create a character from scratch with tons of skills at your disposal. The player is given a lot of freedom and tools which grants a lot of variety. You can play vastly different and try various survival tactics in order to overcome nature and it's threats. Be a fisherman, farmer, hunter, gatherer or a bandit. You're given the choice.The world itself is vast and filled with tons of items, creatures, immersion, lore and danger. It's very intricate and engaging with a great amount of detail. Every task that action that you perform has consequences and keeping your characters alive is really a challenge, furthermore the entire game is designed in a realistic way which only enhances the immersion. From fishing to hideworking or combat, everything is rough and has detail. It's a engrossing and hostile world.A great aspect is the interactive story, despite not having a full blown campaign. You can chose from a variety of character backgrounds which vastly changes the start of your adventure. Start as a well equipped hunter or fisherman but if you're up for the challenge you can play as a runaway slave that is being hunted. You make your own story and it's done with such detail that you feel really immersed. Even though the minimalistic graphics aren't that advanced, the presentation is solid. The small amount of songs and sound effect will still grab your attention, as for the rest the text provides enough flavor to really make you feel like this lonesome adventurer. This is pretty much standard for most roguelike though but this theme really resonates with me compared to other dungeon crawlers.The interface and controls are somewhat unintuitive but once you get used to it, it's really not that much of a deal. It might be a hassle at first to browse through the various menus but it's all set up in a reasonable fashion. That might be the biggest issue about this game, also there aren't many sound effects but it's still solid enough.Overall this is a very lovely game and crafted with such dedication, if this type of game doesn't appeal to you. You will probably get frustrated and not really enjoy it. But if you do, you will be rewarded with a great survival game that actually makes you think about provide a good challenge, while having a strong theme with a realistic tone.Definitely worth the price. Even if you're not sure about this game, you can still download it for free on the official website.

												I cannot recommend this game enough!Though I've only got a short logged playtime on Steam, I've been playin this game for about three years now from its pre-Steam releases.To put into perspective the ungodly amount of effort that has gone into this game, I'll piont out that it has been in development since 1992. I *think* that makes it the game with the longest development time - at least more so than either Dwarf Frotress or the Duke Nukem. 24 years of work, as of the time of this review in 2016.So what can you do in this game? Good question. You might recall how Todd Howard likes to say of Bethesda's releases that you can 'climb any mountain' or 'do anything' - well, you couldn't. In UrW you can come a whole lot closer to doing anything, though!Every aspect of life (bar taking a♥♥♥♥♥♥and ♥♥♥♥ing someone, which is probably for the best) is covered. A massive amount of attention to detail has been made, and there are absolutely shedloads of historically accurate items, foods and activites you can access. What's more, the game (despite being a roguelike and keyboard-based, which may initially pout a lot of people off) is very accessible due to its fantastic in-game wiki.What I've always loved in particular is that you set your own goals, something that no other RPG I've ever seen has done so well:* Want to hunt a bear? Sure, get tracking! But first you need to make sure you're well prepared. Should you take the spear, the bow or both? Is it worth buying a hunting dog to help you out? Maybe you'll need a companion from a local village to cover your back? How much food will you need for the journey? There are so many things to consider.* Exploration is crazy in this game! I mean, the gameworld is literally Finland. The very size. It's enormous.* Perhaps it's time to settle down; building a settlement in UrW is incredibly rewarding, but by no means easy work! I've never found anything as satisfying in a game as having completed a gleaming wooden longhall, complete with mead benches and a roaring hearth. It took me several in-game months to achieve and arrived just in time for winter. Winter is brutal in this game!* If you somehow feel your options aren't already wide enough, the game is incredibly easy to mod! Making and adding mods are both simple processes and widely expand the gameplay; what's more, since modding for the most aprt relies on adding .txt and .png files, there's practically a 0% chance that you could damage your game with mods (unlike certain other franchises), so go crazy!A final note is that the UrW forums having been running for years and in that time the developers Sami and Erkka have been amazing; they have listened to every player suggestion, answered every question they could and are highly aware of what can make the game better. There never has been, and never will be, a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ update. It's been getting better for 24 continuous years, and can only improve in the future! Make sure to visit the game's website and check the future development goals.Thanks for reading this far!
