												"Only when the last tree is cut;only when the last river is polluted;only when the last fish is caught;only then will they realise that you cannot eat money."-Cree Indian proverbThis game is clever in ways most modern 3D survival games can only dream of. Sure, the graphics are dated and controls might feel overwhelming in the beginning, but behind the first impressions hides a truly spectacular survival experience in the forests of Iron Age Finland.Unreal World utilises the mechanics that 2D world offers over 3D to give the player more realistic survival setting. 2D world can speed up the world around you when you perform tasks much more naturally than any game done in 3D could, and the game takes full advantage of this. The days in UrW are 24h, the year is 365 days. When you plant crops they aren't full grown in the next morning. There's also full 4 seasons in a Finnish year. During summer it's warm and the nature is blooming, but after a few months of sunshine it starts to get cold. And it gets really cold. If you are not prepared the winter can freeze you to death in a day and roaming in waist deep snow is exhausting. But even winter has its benefits. Animal tracks are easier to spot in the snow and food lasts for months before it spoils when it's -20c outside 24/7.Animals in the Unreal World are dangerous, but not like in many other games where you'll be beating them off multiple times a day with your fancy swords. In Unreal World even the most dangerous animals, the bears will flee when they spot you 90% of the time, perhaps even more often. They might get curious, smelling your roasting food and stay nearby. Come night they might try to sneak in and steal your food. Specially foxes like to do that. Or they might eat your livestock if you have any. But most of the time they will attack you only after you have provoked them by chasing them, cornering them or by surprising them, sneaking too close. Almost any animal will attack you when cornered, an elk might kick you to the head if you give it no chance to escape.Combat is terrifying. Any time you are attacked there's always a real chance your game will end there. This might sound like a bad game design choice. But in my opinion it makes much more sense this way. The player is not a super-human who could beat of 10 other people with ease. And if you lose in combat you will not wake up in your bed the next morning or something like that. You will be staring at the summary screen of your characters life, that has ended. Some special cases might leave you alive after you lose a battle, the robbers and friendly villagers. Robbers will take all your valuables and villagers will take away stolen property by force if you try to steal from them.Unreal World is the most complete survival experience I have come across, ever. And the best thing is that the author still has ideas of what to add, even if the pace might not be the fastest.Here's a few ways to end your life sooner rather than later in Unreal World, try to avoid:-Throwing a rock at a bear when you are not prepared for battle.-Walking on thin ice in the spring.-Swimming with all your stuff-Fishing with poor skill or poor tools-Eating funny looking mushrooms or plants.

												I don't have a ton of time on steam and still not as much as many people have on the version before steam, however this has to be one of the best rougelikes I've ever played and I still can't believe it isn't more popular. You can do almost anything in the game that you want and the sheer size of the simulation and procedural generation is crazy. Every map is full randomly generated, although certain factions will always inhabit particular areas as that is part of the game's history. (Thereis a full in-game encyclopedia to tell you about just about everything, from were each of the 9 dominant tribes live, how they live, and what tools and skills the use in their daily life) The creators have updated the game for a very very long time and are consistent, I remember stumbling on this accidentally like 10 years ago on their webpage and thought it was awesome. They mix in real pictures to simulate many of the events in the game and locations and if you look past the basic spriting, its a game that shines. The soundtrack is great and the theme song is played on a Kantele, which is apparently a finnish instrument. They use a lot of their heritage in the game as it is based in the real world with mythological stuff thrown on top (but mostly in the form of rituals). You can hunt, fish, trade, fight, build, go bear grylls in Iron Age Finland, basically whatever you choose. Although it is not a super easy game in the beginning, it is rewarding once you figure out the controls and your basics. There are guides available online too that make it easier to start, or just figure it out by trial and error and look through your list of ancestors. It's not that expensive and you'll get more time out of it than AAA titles, except maybe Witcher 3, because damn that is a good, solid game. But this is cheaper, so get this.

												#Note: The game has been free for a long time, and is still free, over at the official website unrealworld.fi .UnReal World is a procedurally generated top down rogue-like survival game set in a low-fantasy yet realistic version of iron age Finland, and because of this, the game is HARD, especially for new players. if you don't survive more than a week, remember that "losing is fun".Luckily, for new players, the developers (A two-man group) have added two tutorials in order to help new players (one simpler, more focused on survival, one on more advanced mechanics).As a rogue-like, the game has a skill system for rating your abilities in everything from timbercraft and construction to fishing and swimming. The base of these stats are dependent on your characters chosen tribe and their physical scores, randomly generated as you create your character. Your skills are then improved as you practice using them.The game was first released in 1992, and it shows, in some ways. The UI can definitely be improved in some areas, among other things, but the devs are constantly improving the game and it is possible these issues are fixed later on. As an example of the overall attention to detail from the developer, The latest update (the first version released on Steam) added improved winter mechanics, making snow and ice thicker and thinner as winter comes and goes and adding the possibility of breaking the ice, adding another highly plausible way of dying during winter. Something else that has been in the game for some time is one of (if not THE most) advanced animal AI that isn't just randomly walking around, like other games.In summary, it's a highly competent survival game, and the Steam version is currently just a way to pay the devs for the amazing amount of work they have done. If you feel like playing the game, go to their website and try the free non-Steam version first before buying it here.

												Ignore what it says about my hours, I've put countless thousands into this game before it came to steam.UnReal World (UrW) is quite simply the richest rogue-like survival in existence, unique in its depth and nuance. Create a character and determine your path to thriving (or dying) in dark ages Finland. Become a settled trapper, an itinerant fisher, a barbaric warmonger, a hunter, a farmer, a trader... many potential paths lie before you, and you may well find yourself taking all of them over the course of a character's life. Foremost, UrW is both brutal and beautiful, crafting a deep narrative through your struggle to survive in a harsh world, where the environment itself can be as deadly as those that dwell in it. I could tell you a hundred stories from my times playing, of cunning victories, cozy campfires, and unexpected demises, but you'd be far better served spending that time creating your own.In Brief:Generate a unique world and roll a character to embark in it. You may also select a starting scenario (take the runaway slave in winter for hardcore mode or one of the training tutorials for a little early boost). From there, you must seek out a source of food, drink, and shelter. How you do so is truly in your hands. Craft items to aid in your endeavor. Collect berries and cook wonderful meals. Tire of lovely vegetarian fare. Set a fence trap and slaughter some wild beasts. Trade hides with foreign merchants for some coveted metal arms. Capture and tame a wild bear, then hire some fellow adventurers and raid a Njeperz camp. Cut their clothes into bandages and roast their bodies over open flames. And most important, establish a base camp to survive the coming cold, for WINTER _IS_ COMING. If you die, it is permanent, which makes every encounter tense and rewarding. I really can't say enough how amazing this game is.Finally, the developer Sami Maaranen is incredible in his dedication to his game and its playerbase. He is always responsive and friendly, and has been continually working on improving the UrW experience for over two decades. If there's anyone in the indie industry that deserves your money, it's him. I first bought UrW after saving for weeks at my minimum wage job in high school over a decade ago. What I got was worth ten times that.BUY THIS GAME! DON'T WAIT! And then play it, and share your stories wide and far.

												While Unreal World is a pretty hardcore roguelike, it's also very enjoyable once you understand how it works.  The game is set in Iron Age Finland, and you must face the hardships that living in such an environment entails. Building a log cabin which will become your base of operations is something else you can, and should, do.  As this game is meant to be as realistic as possible, you'll find building it to be a time-intensive grind as you fall trees and haul them to the construction site, all the while keeping an eye on your hunger bar.  You'll be grateful for it once winter rolls in though.Unreal World is a game that requires a little patience, though there is a reasonably detailed tutorial.  If you enjoy survivial games that reflect the gritty grind of primitive life, you will enjoy this.  The game is still in development, although updates are not very frequent.

Posted: March 6
												If you enjoy inmersive roleplaying within a game, and making up your own story, and letting your imagination take over in place of visuals then this game is for you.  However, if you need animations on screen, rigid questlines, and giant battles then you will not enjoy Unreal World.  It plays very close to the adventure mode in dwarf fortress (just not with ascii graphics) and Im sure some inspiration definately came from dwarf fortress.  When starting the game you create a character through stats and choosing a tribe/ cultural group.  If you explore the help manual with the f1 key then you can find some more information about each tribe.  One thing I really enjoyed was that most of the native tribes (the northern tribes) aren't especially fond of warfare, but are very much in touch with the land and the spirits.After creating your character you get to pick your starting "story" which is thr scenario your character will start in.  Most of the time I end up using the unfortunate hunting trip scenario, very revenant like, but I did not survive being mauled by the bear.What Unreal World lacks visually it makes up for in depth.  The survival mechanics are managable, but it is too possible to not realize that you hadn't packed enough food to last a migration south to warmer climates for the winter.  Also, combat is much more unforgiving (just as it is in dwarf fortress (can you see a theme yet?)) And what seemed like an easy fight can go wrong with a lucky blow to the leg.  The hunting system is my favorite by far!  Tracking, stalking, mix and repeat.  Very realistic, and Im speaking from experience as a hunter myself.  In other games you go look for an animal, you shoot it, and you have enough food for a little while.  Unreal World makes you earn it.  So you found an elk, got close enough for a shot with your bow?  Great, you have mortally wounded it, but it still ran away.  So you will spend the rest of the in game day following blood trails and tracks, and hopefully you find it again.If you do not enjoy creating your own experience in a game then Unreal World is not for you!  End of story.  If you like dwarf fortress, or other survival sims than you will get many hours of enjoyment from yhis game.

												I have seen this game over the years and never put forth the effort to even play it.  but steam shoved it in my face so I gave it a go.  What to compare it to?  Adventure mode in Dwarf Fortress is about the only thing close.  While DF is soo Deep with physics and minutia controls that the interface and commands keep 90% of the potential players away, URW has much lighter controls, but that is compared to DF, compared to pretty much any other game it still has alot of commands... but they are structured much better than DF, and only take about an hour to get a good handle on them (watch wildfirefly12's let play (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e_JW9Zr0Yxs&list=PLUGuQn97METNsvmaro7R1qH5IFxHMXUFX) she gives a pleasant play through of a few characters, and ends the lets play with a massive attack on the hostile tribe (Njerps).  The letsplay will give you pointers to some good mods she uses and also a good walk through of the commands as she uses them, and certain things to watch out for while playing.As to my handful of play throughs, most have ended by falling through the ice while trying to cross rivers or lakes, either too early in the winter or too late in the spring... listen for the ice cracking.  I do recommend starting a few characters that are purely combat and just go on a killing spree of people to get used to the combat and how to fight, it isn't difficult to issue commands, but it does take some practice/experience to plan each strike, and which weapons are better to defend with (let them attack at you while you counterstike their attacks)  Also your cumulative penalties need to be carefully monitored, rest when you need to and reduce your weight burden else you will just think the game is too hard, it isn't you are just literally stacking too much on your character.  it helps with making better quality goods.  Also start a a good quality cook.  you food will go further as each meal will be satisfying.  best starts for newbies are failed hunting trip and lonely settler as both will start you with a real ax, not a stone ax or no ax at all.Last hint, don't build a fire next to your cellar, the heat from the fire will warm your cellar and make all the food in it go bad, LOL and 10/10 for that level of detail.

Posted: March 11, 2016
												edit: I initially gave this game a negative rating, but as you can see, I'm now 40+ hours into the game, so I've now changed it to positive.The reason for the initial negative rating is the rather-unfriendly UI. There are a myriad of keyboard commands you need to remember by heart. Using a mouse as input is not an option, everything is done strictly by keyboard. I'm the kind of gamer who likes to sit back and relax in my chair while clicking on my mouse, rather than hunch over the keyboard in an upright position, so I wasn't pleased in the beginning. The dozens of keyboard commands are difficult to remember and will force you to consult the "help" page every so often.However, if you can tolerate this, Unreal World becomes a beautiful sandbox game. You can do whatever you want, whether it be to become a farmer, hunter, lumberjack, fisherman, bandit, serial killer etc. The main "goal" is to survive winter, which is harsh and deadly, so most of your time will be devoted to hunting and gathering food, and building a suitable shelter for the cold season. How you approach this is up to you. My main complaint (besides the unfriendly UI) is that the game world can feel lonely at times. At present, you're not able to marry anyone or have kids. You do have the option of hiring adventurers and workers, but they will only stay with you for a short time and then leave. You can't move into a village or improve it. The game makes you feel like you're an outcast with no friends or something. You can almost call it a hermit simulator. Overall, though, I find the game enjoyable. If you're into survival or roguelikes, UW is a very good choice.

												When I first saw the reviews for this game, I was really repulsed. People only have 10-100 hours logged in this game. It didn't make sense to me; the normal amount of time investment in roguelikes is entire years. I assumed they were casuals who collect Steam games and don't actually play any.Now after 70 hours of playing myself, I understand why.The game is too damn easy. With the character I'm currently playing, I killed a bear in my first ten minutes of starting the scenario, and now, only a month in in-game time, I'm powerful enough to slaughter the residents of two villages a day. And I ♥♥♥♥ing shouldn't be! I by no means have any plate armour or super weapons. I am a peasant just like them, yet they walk into me like I'm a meat grinder somehow and I leave each village with "shallow cut in right forearm" at best.So, I guess with that being said, this is one of those ♥♥♥♥♥♥ games for children that "can be hard if you deliberately cripple your character, ignore numerous game mechanics entirely, and always restrict yourself to♥♥♥♥♥♥gear" AKA Pokemon. And I ask people who do that sort of♥♥♥♥♥♥ Why? Why play games like Pokemon or UnReal World only to avoid a majority of the content--lest you make it too easy for yourself--instead of just playing a game that's inherently difficult? There's other RPG's out there where you'll actually be challenged just by playing the game normally and utilizing all materials and tactics. Play those and stop pretending this game is hard just because you purposefully break your character's legs to the point where you can't even cut a tree down. That's YOUR actions inciting challenge, not the game's.The first fifteen-thirty hours make the game appear impossible. But honestly in retrospect, I really only struggled with it due to my not knowing how to distribute my time spent on various tasks. You'll lose characters to this confusion. Do not misinterpret this as challenge, it is only the overwhelming amount of skills and ways to gather food that are leading you to death. You'll grasp it all soon and realize it's mathematical boredom. Nothing will intimidate you. You'll have so much food you'll have to throw it away to make room for more food. I had one character with 400 pounds of food in a cellar and I didn't even bother removing it when it all spoiled. If in future updates they change it so that I'm no longer a walking meat grinder who sucks the life out of anything that moves as soon as it enters range, I would very much enjoy playing. One suggestion I have is to make there be 500% less settlements spawning. If there were only one or two within reasonable walking distance of the player, maybe I'd value them enough to not slaughter their sages and steal their livestock. This would probably be easier to implement than tampering with damage multipliers and everything else it takes to nerf or boost characters. I still recmmend the game despite writing nothing but complaints because it took me 70 hours to realize how depthless it all really is. The game maintained this facade that kept me fearful and thinking I was some chess master when I'd succeed in kills. It wasn't till I decimiated my 50th village that I realized "wait a minute. absolutely nothing is a threat to me, even when i'm practically naked and using only a handaxe".Also, I respect the developer despite my major disagreements with some of his methods. You are living the dream, and I think you're a swell guy.So, yeah. 10 bucks for 70 hours of fun? I don't regret this purchase in the slightest, though clearly I had expected this to be years of fun like other, better roguelikes (...that are all free. Ouch).

												I've been playing UrW for about 8 years and I always go back to it. It's a survival game but not of the same ilk that we've been bombarded with lately; there are no zombies that come out at night, etc., but rather it's just you out in the woods. It's a sandbox in that you set your own goals, and the world is always different. One playthrough I was a fisherman trading with nearby villages (until I drowned), another I hunted with a javelin for hides and food (until I was killed by a bear) and another playthrough I found myself starving in the woods and turned to cannibalism (until I was killed by my would be victim).It's permadeath, and you'll die often, but for me this game has been about the journey rather than the destination.It's been worked on since the 90s apparently, and received updates since I've owned it. It's also free on the UrW website, but I recommend that if you play it and enjoy it, and want to support fantastic, involved developers, then throw some cash their way.
